description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

title.narrative: Directives concernant le processus mis en place au titre de l’aide ciblée aux pays dans le cadre du PEF

description.narrative: A travers le cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires, les partenaires de l’Alliance du Vaccin soutiennent les activités de vaccination au niveau national
Gavi’s targeted country assistance aims to share our partners’ specialist skills with the countries we support

title.narrative: À propos de l’aide ciblée aux pays

description.narrative: L’aide ciblée aux pays de Gavi vise à partager les compétences spécialisées de nos partenaires avec les pays que nous soutenons
Through the partners’ engagement framework, Vaccine Alliance partners support countries’ immunisation activities

condition.narrative: Conditions are detailed in the Partners’ engagement framework
Les conditions sont détaillées dans le cadre d'engagement des partenaires

title.narrative: Produce surveillance report for previous 6 months

target.value: Support continuation osurveillance for S. typhi as part of Population Based Infections DiseaseSurveillance at two sites, including Antimicrobial Sensitivity Testing ( AST) to inform TCV NVS preparations

comment.narrative: Completed: From November 2020 to May 2021, a total of 1308 patients eligible for BC were seen, 1175 (89.8%) had a BC collected. Of these, 1155 (98.3%) had BC results but only 716 (62.0%) had adequate blood volume. Of those with BC results, 60 (5.2%) had a postive BC and 37 (3.2%) isolates were possible contaminants. Three S Typhi were isolated (0.4%), one from Asembo and two from Kibera. No isolates were resistant to the common antbiotics.

target.value: Support continuation osurveillance for S. typhi as part of Population Based Infections DiseaseSurveillance at two sites, including Antimicrobial Sensitivity Testing ( AST) to inform TCV NVS preparations

Three S Typhi were isolated (0.4%), one from Asembo and two from Kibera. No isolates were resistant to the common antbiotics.

title.narrative: REC Microplans is available in 80% of Health Facilities in 12 Gavi HSS priority counties with huge numbers of urban, nomadic and migrant populations and used to reduced the numbers of children with zero dose

target.value: Provide Technical support and mentorship to counties to guide Implementation of MR campaign strategies, REC including microplanning (including mapping of unvaccinated children) and PIRI in 12 Counties with major urban, migrant and nomadic populations with special focus on zero dose (unreached) children

comment.narrative: Micro-planning tools finalized and have been adopted by 22 counties, 11 of which are Gavi HSS counties, during the ongoing for the MR vaccination campaign 26th June to 5th July 2021 in 22 counties. The Micro-plans will be adopted by all the remaining counties to guide the planned PIRI to be implemented nationwide

target.value: Provide Technical support and mentorship to counties to guide Implementation of MR campaign strategies, REC including microplanning (including mapping of unvaccinated children) and PIRI in 12 Counties with major urban, migrant and nomadic populations with special focus on zero dose (unreached) children

comment.narrative: Micro-planning tools finalized and have been adopted by 22 counties, 11 of which are Gavi HSS counties, during the ongoing for the MR vaccination campaign 26th June to 5th July 2021 in 22 counties. The Micro-plans will be adopted by all the remaining counties to guide the planned PIRI to be implemented nationwide

title.narrative: 9 UNICEF Supported (50 %) Counties have adopted and are using the BNA, Action Tracker & Scorecards applications for DHIS2 to track performance and make decisions including advocacy for immunization with county leadership

target.value: Strengthening of national health information system (HIS), through better quality and use of immunisation data - through BNA, Action Tracker & Scorecards applications for DHIS2

comment.narrative: Ongoing engagement of the national health information system is being provided. The adoption of BNA action tracker in 9 counties has however been delayed due to engagement of critical national and county staff in Covid19 vaccine deployment.

target.value: Strengthening of national health information system (HIS), through better quality and use of immunisation data - through BNA, Action Tracker & Scorecards applications for DHIS2

comment.narrative: Ongoing engagement of the national health information system is being provided. The adoption of BNA action tracker in 9 counties has however been delayed due to engagement of critical national and county staff in Covid19 vaccine deployment.

target.value: Strengthening of national health information system (HIS), through better quality and use of immunisation data - through BNA, Action Tracker & Scorecards applications for DHIS2

comment.narrative: UNICEF has supported the rollout of Scorecard in all the 47 counties where the scorecard and action tracker is being used. The BNA component is however yet to be rolled out due to competing priorities occasioned by Covid19 pandemic and vaccine rollout

title.narrative: Immunization Scorecard adopted by the17 Gavi HSS supported counties to inform program performance monitoring and advocacy for immunization

comment.narrative: Use of health sector and immunization scorecard has been adopted by all the 17 counties in Kenya and is being used by the National program and counties to advocate with county stakeholders to address inequitable coverage. The use of the scorecard for decision making is being strengthened across the counties and is mostly hampared by inconsistent performance review meetings at county level

Use of health sector and immunization scorecard has been adopted by all the 17 counties in Kenya and is being used by the National program and counties to advocate with county stakeholders to address inequitable coverage. The use of the scorecard for decision making is being strengthened across the counties and is mostly hampared by inconsistent performance review meetings at county level

title.narrative: Post introduction evaluation recommendation implementation plan to address gaps and scale up best practices

target.value: Technical support to Kenya immunisation programme to plan and conduct post introduction evaluation following introduction of yellow fever (YF) and Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccine in 2019

comment.narrative: Kenya introduced various vaccines in 2019 as part of its effort to increase access to life saving vaccines. In 2019 vaccine against human papilloma virus (HPV) was introduced nationally, yellow fever vaccine in two counties of Turkana and West Pokot and malaria vaccine in 8 counties with high prevalence of malaria diseases. WHO recommends the conduct of a post introduction evaluation (PIE) after introduction of new vaccines which is a systematic assessment to determine the impact of the new vaccines into the immunization system. WHO provided technical assistance to Kenya immunization programme to plan for implementation of integrated PIE for HPV, yellow fever and malaria vaccines. WHO coordinated and convened working committee to prepare for the PIE. WHO drafted the integrated PIE concept note, development of questionnaires and piloting of the data collection tools. WHO facilitated data analysis and interpretation to inform the selection of counties for field data collection. Data will be collected using hand held devices using Kobocollect. Data collection is planned to be carried out after implementation of measles rubella vaccination in July 2021. Field data collection will be done in 12 selected counties using mobile phone handsets. The selection of the counties considered the immunization performance so that good, average and poor performing counties are included. Data will then be analyzed to inform development of improvement plan.

target.value: Technical support to Kenya immunisation programme to plan and conduct post introduction evaluation following introduction of yellow fever (YF) and Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccine in 2019

comment.narrative: Kenya introduced various vaccines in 2019 as part of its effort to increase access to life saving vaccines. In 2019 vaccine against human papilloma virus (HPV) was introduced nationally, yellow fever vaccine in two counties of Turkana and West Pokot and malaria vaccine in 8 counties with high prevalence of malaria diseases. WHO recommends the conduct of a post introduction evaluation (PIE) after introduction of new vaccines which is a systematic assessment to determine the impact of the new vaccines into the immunization system. WHO provided technical assistance to Kenya immunization programme to plan for implementation of integrated PIE for HPV, yellow fever and malaria vaccines. WHO coordinated and convened working committee to prepare for the PIE. WHO drafted the integrated PIE concept note, development of questionnaires and piloting of the data collection tools. WHO facilitated data analysis and interpretation to inform the selection of counties for field data collection. Data will be collected using hand held devices using Kobocollect. Data collection is planned to be carried out after implementation of measles rubella vaccination in July 2021. Field data collection will be done in 12 selected counties using mobile phone handsets. The selection of the counties considered the immunization performance so that good, average and poor performing counties are included. Data will then be analyzed to inform development of improvement plan.

title.narrative: Key findings and recommendations of post introduction evaluation to inform strategies to increase and sustain coverage of yellow fever and HPV

target.value: Technical support to Kenya immunisation programme to plan and conduct post introduction evaluation following introduction of yellow fever (YF) and Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccine in 2019

comment.narrative: Post introduction evaluation data collection to generate findings is to be implemented. The findings will inform the recommendation and strategies to increase and sustain coverage of the new vaccines introduced

target.value: Support to update and implement the National Immunization Data Quality Improvement Plan (DQIP)

comment.narrative: Kenya developed its data quality improvement plan 2021-2025 to guide its investments in data. The DQIP is aligned to Kenya immunization strategic plan. WHO led the process of developing the DQIP and coordinated inputs from all stakeholders. The development of the DQIP. The DQIP has a monitoring and evaluation framework that is used to track its implementation. The framework has defined indicators to facilitate tracking of progress. The DQIP is now being used and monitoring of its implementation is an ongoing process

target.value: Support to update and implement the National Immunization Data Quality Improvement Plan (DQIP)

comment.narrative: The Kenya DQIP outlines key activities that the country implementing and strategies to employ to assure availability of quality data to inform programming. WHO in collaboration with other partners are supporting the Kenya Ministry of Health to ensure that the DQIP is being used in all counties. WHO is providing support to ensure that the counties include data quality improvement activities in their work plans in order to secure funding. WHO is advocating for partners to promote the use of the DQIP at all levels.

title.narrative: Updated DQIP rolled out to 80% of Counties

target.value: Support the Kenya National Immunization programme to conduct annual data desk review and implement costed Data Quality Improvement Plan (DQIP)

comment.narrative: The Kenya data quality improvement plan (DQIP) 2021-2025 details the investment areas on data. The DQIP is a guiding document to counties to prioritize data. WHO supports Ministry of Health to disseminate the DQIP to all stakeholders and counties. The DQIP is being implemented and rolled out in all the 47 counties in Kenya.

title.narrative: REC Microplans available and implemented in 80% of Health Facilities in 12 Gavi HSS priority counties with huge numbers of urban, nomadic and migrant populations

target.value: Provide Technical support to the MOH EPI program to extend implementation of REC strategy in additional 12 counties with major urban informal settlements, migrants and nomadic populations that are not adequately reaced with immunization services and introduce HPV, MenA and YF into the National RI system

comment.narrative: All Gavi HSS counties have micro-plans developed to guide MR vaccination campaign. The micro-plans will be adopted to guide implementation of routine immunization and PIRI. HPV/YF PIE: Draft tools for HPV and YF PIE ready with implementation of PIES for HPV, YF and Malaria planned for second half of 2021. Funds prepositioned for the joint PIE. MenA: Vaccination campaign conducted in 2019. Funds received from Gavi for establishment of Surveillance system which will be led by WHO

title.narrative: Document lessons learned from implementing the school strategy for RI

target.value: Develop and implement strategies to engage Primary Schools on RI, including development and dissemination of immunization IECs

comment.narrative: Documentation of lessons learnt has been delayed by competing priorities especially the covid-19 vaccine deployment, surges in covid 19 infections and resignation of the staff under TA who was supporting this deliverable. A short term consultant will be recruited to undertake the evaluation n the second half of 2021

title.narrative: Draft Strategy on a certification system to ensure children joining school are effectively verified for immunization status disseminated to key stakeholders

target.value: Support EPI program operationalize the Presidential directive on collaboration between the MOH and MOE to improve immunization performance

comment.narrative: The accomplishment of this deliverable has experience major delay due to covid-19 pandemic and vaccine deployment. Engagement of the education sector will be accelerated as the country plans to implement the HPV MAC, PIRI and Gavi -EAC HPV grant being managed by UNICEF in the second half of 2021

title.narrative: Gavi Transition Framwork for Kenya is finalized and adopted by MOH by end of Q2 of 2021 TCA project cycle

target.value: A. Provide Technical support to the National level EPI program to generate evidence that will will enable the NVIP to: Effectively engage in the national and county planning and budgeting process including MTEF; Development of Immunization Transition Framework B. Support the development of the Full Portfolio Plan for Kenya-collation of evidence and development of Theory of Change

comment.narrative: The government adopted a health sector wide approach to developing the transition from donor funding. The Transition plan is currently being developed with support of various development partners. Efforts will be accelerated to ensure completion in the second half of 2021. UNICEF is actively participating in the financing and service delivery working groups.

target.value: A. Provide Technical support to the National level EPI program to generate evidence that will will enable the NVIP to: Effectively engage in the national and county planning and budgeting process including MTEF; Development of Immunization Transition Framework B. Support the development of the Full Portfolio Plan for Kenya-collation of evidence and development of Theory of Change

comment.narrative: The government adopted a health sector wide approach to developing the transition from donor funding. The Transition plan is currently being developed with support of various development partners. Efforts will be accelerated to ensure completion in the second half of 2021. UNICEF is actively participating in the financing and service delivery working groups.

title.narrative: Key findings of coverage survey elaborated to inform annual planning

target.value: Support to immunization programme to plan, prepare data collection tools and carry out immunization coverage evaluation survey

comment.narrative: Coverage survey findings provide measurements of immunization programme indicators that can be compared with the administrative data. Denominator challenges pose a great challenge to the interpretation of administrative coverages. Routine immunization indicators were incorporated in the measles rubella (MR) post campaign coverage survey that was implemented in July 2021. The MR supplemental immunization activity was conducted in 22 counties identified as high risk for measles rubella. Additional indicators on routine immunization will be collected in the Kenya demographic health survey (KDHS) in February 2022. WHO contributed in the planning and implementation of the MR post campaign coverage survey. WHO convened immunization stakeholders to coordinate and prepare for the MR SIA, develop the data collection instruments and plan for logistics for field work. Furthermore, WHO is among the lead partners providing technical input in the planning for the up coming KDHS in first half of 2022. From the findings of the MR PCCS, 58% of children aged between 9-59 months received 2 doses of routine MR vaccine with the lowest rates in the coastal region and North Eastern at 38% while Nyanza is at 41%. Coverage for children aged 24-59 months was lower than that for children 9-59 months both at national and regional levels. The national average was 73.6% and the lowest regional coverage was 60% in North Eastern and Coastal region. To note is that Gavi funding for the immunization coverage survey for Kenya was not made available

target.value: Support to immunization programme to plan, prepare data collection tools and carry out immunization coverage evaluation survey

comment.narrative: The immunization coverage survey is planned to be carried out after the implementation of nation-wide periodic intensification of routine through a 100 day rapid results initiative in the second half of 2021

target.value: Support to immunization programme to plan, prepare data collection tools and carry out immunization coverage evaluation survey

comment.narrative: The immunization coverage survey is planned to be carried out after the implementation of nation-wide periodic intensification of routine through a 100 day rapid results initiative in the second half of 2021

title.narrative: Coverage survey field data collection completed

target.value: Support to immunization programme to plan, prepare data collection tools and carry out immunization coverage evaluation survey

comment.narrative: The implementation of national immunization coverage survey has been delayed, but is planned to be undertaken in the second half of 2021 after the 100 day rapid results initiative to intensify routine immunization

title.narrative: All (100%) of equipment procured under Gavi CCEOP Phase 2 are installed and report shared with ICC by end of first half of 2021

target.value: A. Support the EPI program Supply chain and Logistics working group and PMT to effectively manage the supply chain. Sub-Activities: 1: Provide technical support to implement and monitor the 2020 EVMA costed Improvement plan; 2: Provide support to undertake vaccine forecasting, stock management, generate Advocacy materials for timely fund allocation for supply procurement and regularly and timely update and use Stock Management Tool (SMT) and UNICEF Viva; 3. Undertake assessment of reasons for stockouts at subnational levels. 4: Provide support in the CCEOP Operational Deployment Plan Implementation and updating of cold chain inventory 5: Provide support to strengthen the Nation Logistics Working Group: Ensure regular meetings and documentation and followup of action points 6: Support Supply chain systems design to generate evidence for 2020 potfolio planning B. Analyse supplychain data to generate evidence to inform Full Portfolio Planning for Kenya

comment.narrative: There has been delays in procurement and installation of CCEOP Phase 2 that is delinked. The delay has been occasioned by challenges experienced due to the pandemic and covid 19 vaccine deployment. There is ongoing discussion between MoH and Gavi as regards reverting to service bundle to avoid further delays. Drafting of the EVMA Comprehensive Improvement Plan is pending action by EPI manager as the program is experiencing competing priorities related to covid19 vaccine deployment

target.value: A. Support the EPI program Supply chain and Logistics working group and PMT to effectively manage the supply chain. Sub-Activities: 1: Provide technical support to implement and monitor the 2020 EVMA costed Improvement plan; 2: Provide support to undertake vaccine forecasting, stock management, generate Advocacy materials for timely fund allocation for supply procurement and regularly and timely update and use Stock Management Tool (SMT) and UNICEF Viva; 3. Undertake assessment of reasons for stockouts at subnational levels. 4: Provide support in the CCEOP Operational Deployment Plan Implementation and updating of cold chain inventory 5: Provide support to strengthen the Nation Logistics Working Group: Ensure regular meetings and documentation and followup of action points 6: Support Supply chain systems design to generate evidence for 2020 potfolio planning B. Analyse supplychain data to generate evidence to inform Full Portfolio Planning for Kenya

comment.narrative: UNICEF continues to support the SLTWG to accomplish major tasks despite competing priorities and challenges possed by the covid-19 pandemic and vaccine deployment. Regular meetings of the WG is being conducted; Supply chain Systems design is delayed but meeting with stakeholders is being fast tracked; the EVMA draft report is currently under review before finalization. The CCEOP phase 2 delinked proposal and budget approved. Adjustments made to utilize all funds following some savings due to reduced equipment costs. delays occasioned by competing priorities due to Covid19 vaccine deployment. Delivery and installation of the equipment is expected in the second half of 2021

target.value: A. Support the EPI program Supply chain and Logistics working group and PMT to effectively manage the supply chain. Sub-Activities: 1: Provide technical support to implement and monitor the 2020 EVMA costed Improvement plan; 2: Provide support to undertake vaccine forecasting, stock management, generate Advocacy materials for timely fund allocation for supply procurement and regularly and timely update and use Stock Management Tool (SMT) and UNICEF Viva; 3. Undertake assessment of reasons for stockouts at subnational levels. 4: Provide support in the CCEOP Operational Deployment Plan Implementation and updating of cold chain inventory 5: Provide support to strengthen the Nation Logistics Working Group: Ensure regular meetings and documentation and followup of action points 6: Support Supply chain systems design to generate evidence for 2020 potfolio planning B. Analyse supplychain data to generate evidence to inform Full Portfolio Planning for Kenya

comment.narrative: UNICEF continues to support the SLTWG to accomplish major tasks despite competing priorities and challenges possed by the covid-19 pandemic and vaccine deployment. Regular meetings of the WG is being conducted; Supply chain Systems design is delayed but meeting with stakeholders is being fast tracked; the EVMA draft report is currently under review before finalization. The CCEOP phase 2 delinked proposal and budget approved. Adjustments made to utilize all funds following some savings due to reduced equipment costs. delays occasioned by competing priorities due to Covid19 vaccine deployment. Delivery and installation of the equipment is expected in the second half of 2021

title.narrative: 50% of counties report increased coverage for MR2 by end of Q2 in 2021

target.value: A. Provide Technical support to the MOH EPI program to increase demand for MR2, YF and HPV by: 1. Identifying, Implementing and monitoring demand generation strategies (including mapping and engagement with expanded stakeholders e.g schools, social media,major opinion leaders, journalists) 2. Addressing missed opportunities through IPC with healthcare providers including CHVs B. Generate evidence from social data to inform the Full Portfolio planning for Kenya

comment.narrative: While 17 of the 47 (36%) counties reported increase in MR2 coverage in 2019 compared to 2018, only 1 county reported an increase in coverage in 2020. The low coverage is mainly attributable to the covid19 pandemic that negatively impacted access to health services. Demand for MR2 is slowly picking up in several counties and is expected to increase during the planned PIRI in August to November 2021. Demand generation activities including engagement with health workers and stakeholders will be intensified during the 3 months set aside for PIRI.

target.value: A. Provide Technical support to the MOH EPI program to increase demand for MR2, YF and HPV by: 1. Identifying, Implementing and monitoring demand generation strategies (including mapping and engagement with expanded stakeholders e.g schools, social media,major opinion leaders, journalists) 2. Addressing missed opportunities through IPC with healthcare providers including CHVs B. Generate evidence from social data to inform the Full Portfolio planning for Kenya

comment.narrative: While 17 of the 47 (36%) counties reported increase in MR2 coverage in 2019 compared to 2018, only 1 county reported an increase in coverage in 2020. The low coverage is mainly attributable to the covid19 pandemic that negatively impacted access to health services. Demand for MR2 is slowly picking up in several counties and is expected to increase during the planned PIRI in August to November 2021. Demand generation activities including engagement with health workers and stakeholders will be intensified during the 3 months set aside for PIRI.

target.value: Support the Kenya Immunisation programme to plan, conduct Effective Vaccine Management Assesement (EVMA) and contribute to drafting key indicator report

comment.narrative: Kenya effective vaccine management assessment (EVMA) was carried out to collect data using EVM2 tool. Analysis of data was done and findings informed the drafting of Kenya EVM improvement plan. WHO provided technical support to plan and implement the EVMA. WHO facilitated training of MOH and partner staff on the EVM2 tool. WHO in collaboration with UNICEF carried out the analysis of the data, interpretation of findings and drafting of EVM improvement plan. Drafting of the EVM improvement plan is ongoing and is anticipated to be concluded in the second half of 2021.

target.value: Support the Kenya Immunisation programme to plan, conduct Effective Vaccine Management Assesement (EVMA) and contribute to drafting key indicator report

comment.narrative: Kenya effective vaccine management assessment (EVMA) was carried out to collect data using EVM2 tool. Analysis of data was done and findings informed the drafting of Kenya EVM improvement plan. WHO provided technical support to plan and implement the EVMA. WHO facilitated training of MOH and partner staff on the EVM2 tool. WHO in collaboration with UNICEF carried out the analysis of the data, interpretation of findings and drafting of EVM improvement plan. target.value: Support the Kenya Immunisation programme to plan, conduct Effective Vaccine Management Assesement (EVMA) and contribute to drafting key indicator report

comment.narrative: With the increase in the number of vaccines offered by the Kenya immunization programme demands availability of a reliable, robust and resilient system for management of vaccines with adequate storage capacity. Findings of an effective vaccine management assessment (EVMA) will guide the programme for the next five years to improve quality assurance in vaccines logistics and service delivery. Effective vaccine management assessment was carried out and data collected. WHO participated in the planning process for EVMA and data collection. WHO provided technical assistance to adapt the data collection tools, training on use of EVM2 tool. WHO deployed technical staff to counties to collect data during the EVMA. WHO contributed in the deliberations to discuss the EVM findings and prioritization of areas to be reflected in the EVM improvement plan

comment.narrative: Minor delays. Large group meetings were on hold due to COVID restrictions. Nairobi country trainings are completed, Kitui and Busia training has yet to start.

title.narrative: Data from supportive supervision data availabe and used for decision making

target.value: Use of routine supportive supervision data for decision making to improve routine immunization services.

comment.narrative: Minor delays. Large group meetings were on hold due to COVID restrictions. Once trainings are completed, data collection can start. Additional electronic training modules are also in the works to expand to additional counties.

comment.narrative: On track. Completed two additional county level trainings by September on the supportive supervision tool within DHIS2 and began development of online training platform with digital training videos for supportive supervision for country level scale up.
